explanation:
Required symbols and why they are needed to decide MISRA ‘‘for loop shall be well-formed’’ for the for-loop: for (unsigned i = 0; i < file->cfg->attr_count; i++) { ... }

- lfs_dir_get
  - This function is called inside the loop body (reads user attribute into file->cfg->attrs[i].buffer). MISRA requires the behaviour of the loop body (including any functions it calls) be examined to ensure they do not modify objects used in the loop condition (file->cfg->attr_count) or the loop counter. The implementation and signature of lfs_dir_get are needed to determine whether it has any side effects on file, file->cfg, or attr_count.

- lfs_dir_getslice
  - lfs_dir_get calls lfs_dir_getslice (per the static call graph). To fully understand the side effects of lfs_dir_get (and thus the loop body), the callee(s) of lfs_dir_get must be inspected for any modifications to objects referenced in the loop condition.

- lfs_tag_size
  - lfs_dir_get calls lfs_tag_size. Even utility functions can read/compute or manipulate tag-related state; include it so the analyzer can confirm it has no side effects that would affect objects used in the for second clause.

- struct lfs_file_config
  - The loop condition reads file->cfg->attr_count. The definition of struct lfs_file_config (types and layout of attr_count and attrs[]) is required to determine whether attr_count is a plain scalar that can be modified by the loop body or by functions called in the body (e.g., via aliasing), and to inspect whether attrs[i].buffer/size access could alias attr_count.

- struct lfs_file_t
  - The loop uses file (file->cfg, file->flags). The file structure definition is needed to determine aliasing relationships (e.g., whether file->m or other members passed into lfs_dir_get might alias file->cfg or attr_count) and to check whether the loop counter or loop-condition objects could be modified directly or indirectly by code in the loop body.

- LFS_READONLY
  - The presence/absence of the write branch (which sets file->flags |= LFS_F_DIRTY and checks sizes) depends on this compile-time macro. Whether that branch is compiled affects which side effects are present in the loop body; the analyzer must know this macro's value to reason about the body behaviour for MISRA compliance.

- LFS_O_RDONLY
  - The conditional that guards the lfs_dir_get call is ((file->flags & LFS_O_RDONLY) == LFS_O_RDONLY). To decide if lfs_dir_get will execute (and thus whether its side effects are relevant), the analyzer needs the intended semantics/definition of LFS_O_RDONLY and how file->flags is initialized/modified.

Notes:
- The primary concern for MISRA here is whether the second clause (i < file->cfg->attr_count) uses objects that are modified in the loop body (directly or via called functions). The listed symbols are those necessary to determine possible side effects and aliasing that could affect file->cfg->attr_count (or the loop counter i) during loop execution.
- If more detailed side-effect analysis is required, the full implementations (and transitive callees) of lfs_dir_get and its callees should be examined; the immediate callees are included to start that analysis.
